sourceDesc.p:
This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed REED collections - Inns of Court, Ecclesiastical London, and Civic London to 1558. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

REED London Online is a prototype online collection developing from the Records of Early English Drama (REED) in partnership with the Canadian Writing Research Collaboratory (CWRC) and supported by Bucknell University. It aims to establish an openly accessible online scholarly and pedagogical resource of London-centric documentary, editorial, and bibliographic materials related to performance, theatre, and music spanning the period 1100-1642. With support from an NHPRC-Mellon Planning Grant for Digital Edition Publishing Cooperatives and CANARIE Research Software Program grants, REED London is creating new environments for scholarly presentation of archival materials gathered from legal, ecclesiastical, civic, political, and personal archival sources in and around London. The objective of the REED London project team is to build a stable, extensible publication environment that optimizes access to these compiled materials in ways that respond to scholars’ research interests across disciplines. Consulting with other planning grant recipients will be invaluable to ensuring that REED London’s production and publication environment is in line with standards laid out in the NHPRC-Mellon grant objectives. It is hoped that the progress REED London and CWRC make will also inform the larger dialogue about best practices among funded teams.

div.ab: Memorandum Trinitatis vijo Edwardi iiijti accidit quod quedam facta ad arma partita inter antonium Wydevile dominum de scales ex vna parte & Bastardum filium ducis Burgundie: ex altera parte in campo quodam loco vocato smythfeld essent facienda: super quo dominus Rex mandauit iiijor hospicijs Curie: quod quodlibet hospicium iuberet iiij homines . eiusdem hospicij armatos ad attendendum super dictum dominum Regem in predicto loco tempore faciendi dicta facta quod mandatum improuide fuit consensum ex ijbus hospicijs templi contra voluntatem & consensum . nostramnostram: for nostrum: set postea: per omnia consensum: Et ista societas electauit iiij socios: viz. Willelmum Debenham Robertum Debenham Iohannem Gygges & Iohannem Ioyce bene armatos &c & Insuper an conduxerunt in Grosso quoddam Skeffald . pro ludendis factis &c. pro quo soluerunt: C s. & pro dictis armatis: & suorum expensis xl s.: super quo consensum fuit per eandem societatem: quod quilibet socius presens in villa soluet ij s. & quilibet absens xij d.

Memorandum that in the Trinity (term) in the seventh (year of the reign) of Edward IV it happened that certain deeds of arms shared between Anthony Wydevill, Lord Scales, on the one part, and the bastard son of the Duke of Burgundy on the other part, would be performed in a certain place called Smithfield; regarding which the lord king sent word to the four Inns of Court that each Inn should bid four armed men of the same Inn to attend on the said lord king in the aforesaid place, at the time of the performing of the said deed. That command was imprudently agreed to by the two Inns of the temple against our will and consent, but afterwards it was agreed to by all. And this society elected four fellows, namely, William Debenham, Robert Debenham, John Gygges, and John Joyce, well armed, etc, and moreover they hired in (its) entirety a certain scaffold for playing the deeds (of arms), for which they paid 100s, and for the aforesaid armed men and for their expenses, 40s. Regarding which (expenses) it was agreed by the same society that any fellow present in the town should pay 2s, and any absent, 12d.

div.head: Endnote
div.p: Antoine, count of La Roche (‘Bastardum filium ducis Burgundie’), came to England in 1467 to arrange a marriage between his brother, Charles, count of Charolais, and Lady Margaret, sister of Edward IV. The joust, which took place in June, is described in John Stow, The Annales of England (London, 1592; STC: 23334), 689–90. Anthony Wydevill, Lord Scales, was the victor. On the general subject of jousts and tournaments, see Nelson (ed), Inns of Court, p 916, endnote to LI Arch: A1a1 f 62v.
